title: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer aims dig at Liverpool players after draw vs Man Utd
text:
Ole Gunnar Solskjaer hit back at complaints from Liverpool’s players (PA Wire)

Manchester United manager Ole Gunnar Solskjaer has aimed a dig at Liverpool’s players after they wanted Marcus Rashford’s goal to be disallowed during the 1-1 draw at Old Trafford.

Rashford opened the scoring in the first half as he met Daniel James’ cross to fire past Alisson from close range.

Liverpool’s players and Jurgen Klopp were adamant that Divock Origi had been fouled by Victor Lindelof moments before Rashford’s goal.

But after a VAR check United’s goal was allowed to stand, much to the dismay of Klopp and Liverpool’s players.

Earlier this week, Liverpool’s players were pictured playing basketball in training before their match against United.

And Solskjaer couldn’t help himself as he provided a sneaky reference to that incident when he was asked about Rashford’s goal.

Asked if he thought it was a foul on Origi in the build up, Solskjaer replied: ‘No chance… we’re not playing basketball.

‘He touched him but it’s not a clear and obvious error. I don’t think it’s a foul.’

VAR did not consider there to be enough contact on Divock Origi (Sky Sports)

Solskjaer also revealed that he is keen for his United side to play more direct following their poor start to the campaign.

‘We are better when he attack quickly, no dilly-dallying on the ball,’ said the United manager.

‘Playing the ball forward doesn’t have to be a counter attack but you need to be more direct, take more risks, be braver.

‘It doesn’t matter if you lose the ball up there because you can win it back.

‘Being more direct helped us.’
